The emergent ray ($	ext{O'H}$) from a rectangular glass slab is **parallel to the direction of the incident ray** ($	ext{EO}$) because the bending at the two parallel faces is equal and opposite.
The light ray is shifted **sideward slightly** (lateral displacement).

one_mark_questions.question: What happens to a light ray when it enters from a rarer medium to a denser medium? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: When a light ray enters from a rarer medium to a denser medium... the ray bends towards the normal.

one_mark_questions.question: What happens to a light ray when it enters from a denser medium to a rarer medium? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: When a light ray enters from a denser medium to a rarer medium... the ray bends away from the normal.

one_mark_questions.question: How is the emergent ray from a rectangular glass slab related to the incident ray? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The emergent ray... is parallel to the direction of the incident ray.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the slight sideward shift of a light ray passing through a glass slab called? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The light ray is shifted sideward slightly (lateral displacement).

two_mark_questions.question: Describe the bending of light at both surfaces as it passes through a rectangular glass slab (from air to glass, then glass to air). (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: When a light ray enters from a rarer medium (air) to a denser medium (glass), the ray bends towards the normal. When it exits from the denser medium (glass) to a rarer medium (air), the ray bends away from the normal.

two_mark_questions.question: Why is the emergent ray from a rectangular glass slab parallel to the incident ray? (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: The emergent ray is parallel to the direction of the incident ray because the bending at the two parallel faces (air-glass and glass-air) is equal and opposite.

three_mark_questions.question: Explain the full path of a light ray passing through a rectangular glass slab. Mention the bending at both surfaces and the final path of the emergent ray. (3 marks)
three_mark_questions.answer: When a light ray enters from a rarer medium (like air) to a denser medium (like glass), it bends towards the normal. Then, when the ray exits the denser medium back into the rarer medium, it bends away from the normal. Because the bending at the two parallel faces is equal and opposite, the emergent ray is parallel to the direction of the incident ray, although it is shifted sideward slightly (this is lateral displacement).

key_concepts: The extent of the change in light direction is expressed in terms of the **refractive index ($	ext{n}$)**.
Light travels **fastest in vacuum** with speed $3 	imes 10^{8} 	ext{ m } 	ext{s}^{-1}$.

The refractive index of medium 2 with respect to medium 1 ($	ext{n}_{21}$) is the ratio of the speed of light in medium 1 ($	ext{v}_1$) to the speed of light in medium 2 ($	ext{v}_2$): $$n_{21} =  rac{v_1}{v_2}$$

The **absolute refractive index** ($	ext{n}_{	ext{m}}$) is the refractive index of a medium with respect to **vacuum or air**: $$n_m =  rac{	ext{Speed of light in air (c)}}{	ext{Speed of light in the medium (v)}}$$
The ability of a medium to refract light is expressed in terms of its **optical density**, which is **not the same as mass density**.
The medium with the **larger refractive index** is **optically denser**.
The speed of light is **higher in a rarer medium** than in a denser medium.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the refractive index (n)? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The extent of the change in light direction [due to refraction] is expressed in terms of the refractive index (n).

one_mark_questions.question: What is the speed of light in a vacuum? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Light travels fastest in vacuum with speed $3 \times 10^{8} \text{ m } \text{s}^{-1}$.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the absolute refractive index ($n_m$)? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The absolute refractive index ($n_m$) is the refractive index of a medium with respect to vacuum or air.

one_mark_questions.question: What is optical density? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The ability of a medium to refract light is expressed in terms of its optical density.

one_mark_questions.question: Is optical density the same as mass density? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: No, optical density... is not the same as mass density.

one_mark_questions.question: Which medium is considered 'optically denser': one with a larger or smaller refractive index? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The medium with the larger refractive index is optically denser.

one_mark_questions.question: How does the speed of light in a rarer medium compare to a denser medium? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The speed of light is higher in a rarer medium than in a denser medium.

two_mark_questions.question: Define the refractive index of medium 2 with respect to medium 1 ($n_{21}$) and provide its formula. (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: The refractive index of medium 2 with respect to medium 1 ($n_{21}$) is the ratio of the speed of light in medium 1 ($v_1$) to the speed of light in medium 2 ($v_2$). The formula is: $$n_{21} = \frac{v_1}{v_2}$$

two_mark_questions.question: Define the absolute refractive index ($n_m$) of a medium and provide its formula. (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: The absolute refractive index ($n_m$) is the refractive index of a medium with respect to vacuum or air. The formula is: $$n_m = \frac{\text{Speed of light in air (c)}}{\text{Speed of light in the medium (v)}}$$

two_mark_questions.question: What is optical density, and how is it related to the refractive index? (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: The ability of a medium to refract light is expressed in terms of its optical density. The medium with the larger refractive index is the one that is optically denser.

two_mark_questions.question: Explain the relationship between optical density and the speed of light in a medium. (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: The medium with the larger refractive index is optically denser. The speed of light is higher in an optically rarer medium than in an optically denser medium.

three_mark_questions.question: What is the absolute refractive index of a medium? Write its formula. What is the speed of light in a vacuum? (3 marks)
three_mark_questions.answer:
The **absolute refractive index** ($n_m$) is the refractive index of a medium with respect to vacuum or air. 
The formula is: $$n_m = \frac{\text{Speed of light in air (c)}}{\text{Speed of light in the medium (v)}}$$ 
Light travels fastest in vacuum with a speed of $3 \times 10^{8} \text{ m } \text{s}^{-1}$.

three_mark_questions.question: Explain the concepts of an 'optically denser' and 'optically rarer' medium. (3 marks)
three_mark_questions.answer:
The ability of a medium to refract light is its optical density. 
1. **Optically Denser Medium:** The medium with the larger refractive index. The speed of light is lower in this medium. 
2. **Optically Rarer Medium:** The medium with the lower refractive index. The speed of light is higher in this medium.

key_concepts: A **lens** is a transparent material bound by two surfaces, of which one or both are spherical.
A **convex lens** (thicker at the middle) is a **converging lens** because it converges light rays.
A **concave lens** (thicker at the edges) is a **diverging lens** because it diverges light rays.
A lens has **two centres of curvature ($	ext{C}_1$ and $	ext{C}_2$)**.
The imaginary straight line passing through the two centres of curvature is the **principal axis**.
The central point of a lens is its **optical centre ($	ext{O}$)**.
A ray of light through the **optical centre ($	ext{O}$) passes without suffering any deviation**.
A lens has **two principal foci ($	ext{F}_1$ and $	ext{F}_2$)**.
The distance of the principal focus from the optical centre is the **focal length ($	ext{f}$)**.

one_mark_questions.question: What is a lens? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: A lens is a transparent material bound by two surfaces, of which one or both are spherical.

one_mark_questions.question: What is a convex lens? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: A convex lens is thicker at the middle [than at the edges].

one_mark_questions.question: What is a concave lens? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: A concave lens is thicker at the edges [than at the middle].

one_mark_questions.question: What is another name for a convex lens, and why? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: A convex lens... is a converging lens because it converges light rays.

one_mark_questions.question: What is another name for a concave lens, and why? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: A concave lens... is a diverging lens because it diverges light rays.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the optical centre (O) of a lens? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The central point of a lens is its optical centre (O).

one_mark_questions.question: What happens to a ray of light that passes through the optical centre of a lens? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: A ray of light through the optical centre (O) passes without suffering any deviation.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the principal axis of a lens? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The imaginary straight line passing through the two centres of curvature is the principal axis.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the focal length (f) of a lens? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The distance of the principal focus from the optical centre is the focal length (f).

one_mark_questions.question: How many centres of curvature does a lens have? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: A lens has two centres of curvature ($C_1$ and $C_2$).

one_mark_questions.question: How many principal foci does a lens have? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: A lens has two principal foci ($F_1$ and $F_2$).

two_mark_questions.question: Differentiate between a convex and a concave lens based on their shape and their action on light. (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer:
A **convex lens** is thicker at the middle and is a **converging lens** because it converges light rays. 
A **concave lens** is thicker at the edges and is a **diverging lens** because it diverges light rays.

two_mark_questions.question: Define the principal axis and the optical centre of a lens. (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer:
The **principal axis** is the imaginary straight line passing through the two centres of curvature. 
The **optical centre (O)** is the central point of a lens.

two_mark_questions.question: What is the key property of a ray of light passing through the optical centre of a lens? (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: A ray of light passing through the optical centre (O) of a lens is unique because it passes through without suffering any deviation (it does not bend).

three_mark_questions.question: Define the following for a spherical lens: (a) Optical Centre, (b) Principal Axis, (c) Focal Length. (3 marks)
three_mark_questions.answer:
(a) **Optical Centre (O):** The central point of a lens. A ray of light passing through it suffers no deviation. 
(b) **Principal Axis:** The imaginary straight line passing through the two centres of curvature. 
(c) **Focal Length (f):** The distance of the principal focus from the optical centre.

three_mark_questions.question: Explain why a convex lens is called 'converging' and a concave lens is called 'diverging'. (3 marks)
three_mark_questions.answer:
A **convex lens** is thicker at the middle. When parallel rays of light pass through it, it bends them *inwards*, causing them to meet, or **converge**, at a point (the principal focus). 
A **concave lens** is thicker at the edges. When parallel rays of light pass through it, it bends them *outwards*, causing them to spread apart or **diverge**.

key_concepts: The nature, position, and relative size of the image formed by a **convex lens** depends on the position of the object (similar to a concave mirror).
A **concave lens** will **always** give a **virtual, erect, and diminished image**, irrespective of the position of the object.

one_mark_questions.question: What determines the nature, position, and relative size of the image formed by a convex lens? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The nature, position, and relative size of the image formed by a convex lens depends on the position of the object.

one_mark_questions.question: What are the three characteristics of an image *always* formed by a concave lens? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: A concave lens will always give a virtual, erect, and diminished image.

one_mark_questions.question: Does the image formed by a concave lens depend on the position of the object? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: No, it gives a virtual, erect, and diminished image, irrespective of the position of the object.

one_mark_questions.question: The image formation of a convex lens is similar to which type of *mirror*? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The image formed by a convex lens depends on the position of the object (similar to a concave mirror).

two_mark_questions.question: Describe the image formed by a concave lens. (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: A concave lens will always give a virtual, erect, and diminished image, irrespective of the position of the object.

two_mark_questions.question: Compare the image formation in a convex lens versus a concave lens. (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: In a convex lens, the nature, position, and relative size of the image depend on the position of the object (it can be real or virtual, magnified or diminished). In a concave lens, the image is always virtual, erect, and diminished, irrespective of the position of the object.

subtopics.subtopic_name: Image Formation in Lenses Using Ray Diagrams
key_concepts: **Ray (i):** A ray parallel to the principal axis, after refraction, **passes through $	ext{F}$** (convex) or **appears to diverge from $	ext{F}$** (concave).
**Ray (ii):** A ray passing through $	ext{F}$ (convex) or appearing to meet at $	ext{F}$ (concave), after refraction, **emerges parallel** to the principal axis.
**Ray (iii):** A ray of light passing through the **optical centre ($	ext{O}$) will emerge without any deviation**.

one_mark_questions.question: What happens to a ray parallel to the principal axis after it refracts through a convex lens? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: A ray parallel to the principal axis, after refraction, passes through F (convex).

one_mark_questions.question: What happens to a ray parallel to the principal axis after it refracts through a concave lens? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: A ray parallel to the principal axis, after refraction... appears to diverge from F (concave).

one_mark_questions.question: What is the path of a ray that passes through the principal focus (F) of a convex lens *after* refraction? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: A ray passing through F (convex)... after refraction, emerges parallel to the principal axis.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the path of a ray that is directed towards the principal focus (F) of a concave lens *after* refraction? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: A ray... appearing to meet at F (concave), after refraction, emerges parallel to the principal axis.

one_mark_questions.question: What happens to a ray of light that passes through the optical centre (O) of a lens? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: A ray of light passing through the optical centre (O) will emerge without any deviation.

two_mark_questions.question: State the rule for a ray parallel to the principal axis for both (a) a convex lens and (b) a concave lens. (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer:
(a) For a convex lens, the ray passes through the principal focus (F) after refraction. 
(b) For a concave lens, the ray appears to diverge from the principal focus (F) after refraction.

two_mark_questions.question: State the rule for a ray passing through (or directed towards) the principal focus F for both (a) a convex lens and (b) a concave lens. (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer:
(a) For a convex lens, a ray passing through F will emerge parallel to the principal axis after refraction. 
(b) For a concave lens, a ray appearing to meet at F will emerge parallel to the principal axis after refraction.

three_mark_questions.question: List the three standard rays used to construct ray diagrams for lenses and describe the path of each one. (3 marks)
three_mark_questions.answer:
1. **Ray parallel to axis:** A ray parallel to the principal axis, after refraction, passes through F (convex) or appears to diverge from F (concave). 
2. **Ray through/towards F:** A ray passing through F (convex) or appearing to meet at F (concave), after refraction, emerges parallel to the principal axis. 
3. **Ray through Optical Centre:** A ray of light passing through the optical centre (O) will emerge without any deviation.

key_concepts: For lenses, the sign convention is similar to mirrors, but **all measurements are taken from the optical centre ($	ext{O}$)**.
The focal length ($	ext{f}$) of a **convex lens is positive**.
The focal length ($	ext{f}$) of a **concave lens is negative**.

one_mark_questions.question: From what point are all measurements taken in the sign convention for spherical lenses? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: For lenses... all measurements are taken from the optical centre (O).

one_mark_questions.question: What is the sign of the focal length (f) for a convex lens? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The focal length (f) of a convex lens is positive.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the sign of the focal length (f) for a concave lens? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The focal length (f) of a concave lens is negative.

two_mark_questions.question: State the sign convention for the focal length of (a) a convex lens and (b) a concave lens. (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer:
(a) The focal length of a convex lens is positive. 
(b) The focal length of a concave lens is negative.

two_mark_questions.question: What is the main similarity and main difference in the sign convention for lenses compared to mirrors? (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: The sign convention is similar to mirrors (e.g., left is negative, right is positive). The main difference is that all measurements are taken from the optical centre (O) for lenses, whereas they are taken from the pole (P) for mirrors.

key_concepts: The **Lens Formula** relates the object distance ($	ext{u}$), image distance ($	ext{v}$), and focal length ($	ext{f}$): $$ rac{1}{v}- rac{1}{u}= rac{1}{f}$$
The magnification ($	ext{m}$) produced by a lens is the ratio of image height ($	ext{h'}$) to object height ($	ext{h}$): $$m= rac{h'}{h}$$
Magnification is also related to the distances: $$m= rac{v}{u}$$

one_mark_questions.question: What is the Lens Formula? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The Lens Formula relates the object distance (u), image distance (v), and focal length (f): $$\frac{1}{v}-\frac{1}{u}=\frac{1}{f}$$

one_mark_questions.question: What is the formula for magnification (m) using image height (h') and object height (h)? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The magnification (m) is the ratio of image height (h') to object height (h): $$m=\frac{h'}{h}$$

one_mark_questions.question: What is the formula for magnification (m) using image distance (v) and object distance (u)? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Magnification is also related to the distances: $$m=\frac{v}{u}$$

two_mark_questions.question: State the Lens Formula and the magnification formula in terms of object and image distance. (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer:
The Lens Formula is: $$\frac{1}{v}-\frac{1}{u}=\frac{1}{f}$$ 
The magnification formula is: $$m=\frac{v}{u}$$

two_mark_questions.question: What is magnification? State the two ways it can be calculated using the given formulas. (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer:
The magnification (m) produced by a lens is the ratio of image height (h') to object height (h). 
Formula 1: $$m=\frac{h'}{h}$$ 
Formula 2: $$m=\frac{v}{u}$$

three_mark_questions.question: State the Lens Formula and both formulas for calculating magnification (m). (3 marks)
three_mark_questions.answer:
The Lens Formula is: $$\frac{1}{v}-\frac{1}{u}=\frac{1}{f}$$ 
The magnification formula using heights is: $$m=\frac{h'}{h}$$ 
The magnification formula using distances is: $$m=\frac{v}{u}$$

key_concepts: The **power ($	ext{P}$) of a lens** expresses its degree of convergence or divergence of light rays.
The power of a lens is defined as the **reciprocal of its focal length ($	ext{f}$)**: $$P= rac{1}{f}$$
The **SI unit of power** of a lens is **dioptre ($	ext{D}$)**, where $1	ext{ D} = 1	ext{ m}^{-1}$ (if $	ext{f}$ is expressed in metres).
The power ($	ext{P}$) of a **convex lens is positive**.
The power ($	ext{P}$) of a **concave lens is negative**.
The net power of lenses placed in contact is the algebraic sum of the individual powers: $	ext{P} = 	ext{P}_1 + 	ext{P}_2 + 	ext{P}_3 + \dots$

one_mark_questions.question: What does the power (P) of a lens express? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The power (P) of a lens expresses its degree of convergence or divergence of light rays.

one_mark_questions.question: How is the power of a lens defined in relation to its focal length (f)? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The power of a lens is defined as the reciprocal of its focal length (f): $$P=\frac{1}{f}$$

one_mark_questions.question: What is the SI unit of the power of a lens? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The SI unit of power of a lens is dioptre (D).

one_mark_questions.question: How is one dioptre (1 D) defined? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: 1 D = 1 mâ»Â¹ (if f is expressed in metres).

one_mark_questions.question: What is the sign of the power (P) for a convex lens? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The power (P) of a convex lens is positive.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the sign of the power (P) for a concave lens? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The power (P) of a concave lens is negative.

one_mark_questions.question: How is the net power of several lenses placed in contact calculated? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The net power of lenses placed in contact is the algebraic sum of the individual powers: $$P = P_1 + P_2 + P_3 + \dots$$

two_mark_questions.question: Define the power of a lens and state its SI unit. (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: The power (P) of a lens expresses its degree of convergence or divergence of light rays. It is defined as the reciprocal of its focal length ($P=1/f$). The SI unit of power is the dioptre (D).

two_mark_questions.question: What is one dioptre? What must be the unit of focal length when calculating power in dioptres? (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: One dioptre (1 D) is the unit of power of a lens. It is defined as 1 D = 1 mâ»Â¹. This means the focal length (f) must be expressed in metres to calculate power in dioptres.

two_mark_questions.question: State the sign convention for the power (P) of (a) a convex lens and (b) a concave lens. (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer:
(a) The power (P) of a convex lens is positive. 
(b) The power (P) of a concave lens is negative.

two_mark_questions.question: A +2.0 D lens and a -1.5 D lens are placed in contact. What is the net power of the combination? (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer:
The net power is the algebraic sum of the individual powers. 
$$P = P_1 + P_2$$ 
$$P = (+2.0 \text{ D}) + (-1.5 \text{ D}) = +0.5 \text{ D}$$

three_mark_questions.question: Define the power of a lens. State its formula, its SI unit, and the sign convention for both convex and concave lenses. (3 marks)
three_mark_questions.answer:
The **power (P)** of a lens expresses its degree of convergence or divergence. 
- **Formula:** It is the reciprocal of its focal length: $$P = \frac{1}{f}$$ 
- **SI Unit:** The unit is the **dioptre (D)**, where 1 D = 1 mâ»Â¹. 
- **Sign Convention:** The power of a convex lens is positive, and the power of a concave lens is negative.

chapter_name: The Human Eye and the Colourful World

key_concepts: The human eye is one of the most valuable and sensitive sense organs, enabling us to see the world and colours around us.
The human eye is like a **camera**.
The eye's lens system forms an image on a light-sensitive screen called the **retina**.
Light enters the eye through a thin membrane called the **cornea**.
The cornea forms the **transparent bulge** on the front surface of the eyeball.
The eyeball is approximately spherical with a diameter of about **2.3 cm**.
Most of the **refraction** for the light rays entering the eye occurs at the **outer surface of the cornea**.
The **crystalline lens** provides the **finer adjustment of focal length** required to focus objects at different distances on the retina.
The **iris** is a dark muscular diaphragm behind the cornea that **controls the size of the pupil**.
The **pupil** regulates and controls the **amount of light entering the eye**.
The eye lens forms an **inverted real image** of the object on the retina.
The retina is a delicate membrane with an enormous number of **light-sensitive cells**.
Light-sensitive cells get activated upon illumination, generate **electrical signals**, which are sent to the brain via the **optic nerves**.

one_mark_questions.question: What part of the eye is the light-sensitive screen where an image is formed? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The eye's lens system forms an image on a light-sensitive screen called the retina.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the cornea? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Light enters the eye through a thin membrane called the cornea. (It forms the transparent bulge on the front surface).

one_mark_questions.question: What is the approximate diameter of the human eyeball? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The eyeball is approximately spherical with a diameter of about 2.3 cm.

one_mark_questions.question: Where does most of the refraction occur for light entering the eye? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Most of the refraction... occurs at the outer surface of the cornea.

one_mark_questions.question: What part of the eye provides the *finer adjustment* of focal length? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The crystalline lens provides the finer adjustment of focal length.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the iris? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The iris is a dark muscular diaphragm behind the cornea.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the function of the iris? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: [The iris] controls the size of the pupil.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the function of the pupil? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The pupil regulates and controls the amount of light entering the eye.

one_mark_questions.question: What kind of image does the eye lens form on the retina? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The eye lens forms an inverted real image of the object on the retina.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the retina? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The retina is a delicate membrane with an enormous number of light-sensitive cells.

one_mark_questions.question: What do the light-sensitive cells in the retina do when illuminated? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Light-sensitive cells get activated upon illumination, generate electrical signals.

one_mark_questions.question: How are signals from the retina sent to the brain? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: [Electrical signals] are sent to the brain via the optic nerves.

two_mark_questions.question: What is the function of the pupil, and what part of the eye controls its size? (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: The pupil regulates and controls the amount of light entering the eye. The iris, a dark muscular diaphragm, controls the size of the pupil.

two_mark_questions.question: Differentiate between the function of the cornea and the crystalline lens regarding refraction. (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: Most of the refraction for the light rays entering the eye occurs at the outer surface of the cornea. The crystalline lens provides the finer adjustment of focal length required to focus objects on the retina.

two_mark_questions.question: What is the retina, and what type of image is formed on it? (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: The retina is a delicate membrane with an enormous number of light-sensitive cells. The eye lens forms an inverted real image of the object on the retina.

two_mark_questions.question: Explain how the brain 'sees' an image. (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: The retina's light-sensitive cells get activated upon illumination and generate electrical signals. These signals are then sent to the brain via the optic nerves.

three_mark_questions.question: Describe the function of the iris, pupil, and crystalline lens. (3 marks)
three_mark_questions.answer:
1. **Iris:** A dark muscular diaphragm that controls the size of the pupil. 
2. **Pupil:** An opening that regulates and controls the amount of light entering the eye. 
3. **Crystalline lens:** Provides the finer adjustment of focal length required to focus the image on the retina.

three_mark_questions.question: Describe the journey of light from the time it enters the eye to the point where a signal is sent to the brain. (3 marks)
three_mark_questions.answer: Light enters through the cornea, where most refraction occurs. It then passes through the pupil (whose size is controlled by the iris) and through the crystalline lens (which fine-tunes the focus). The lens forms an inverted real image on the retina. Light-sensitive cells in the retina are activated and generate electrical signals, which are sent to the brain via optic nerves.

four_mark_questions.question: Describe the function of the following parts of the human eye: (a) Cornea, (b) Iris, (c) Crystalline Lens, (d) Retina. (4 marks)
four_mark_questions.answer:
(a) **Cornea:** The transparent front membrane. Most of the refraction of light occurs at its outer surface. 
(b) **Iris:** A dark muscular diaphragm that controls the size of the pupil. 
(c) **Crystalline Lens:** Provides the finer adjustment of focal length to focus the image on the retina. 
(d) **Retina:** The light-sensitive screen at the back of the eye. It contains light-sensitive cells that generate electrical signals when illuminated.

key_concepts: The eye lens is composed of a fibrous, jelly-like material whose curvature can be modified by the **ciliary muscles**.
The change in the curvature of the eye lens changes its **focal length**.
When the ciliary muscles are relaxed, the lens becomes thin, its focal length increases, enabling us to see **distant objects clearly**.
When the ciliary muscles contract, the lens becomes thicker, its focal length decreases, enabling us to see **nearby objects clearly**.
The ability of the eye lens to adjust its focal length is called **accommodation**.
The minimum distance, at which objects can be seen most distinctly without strain, is called the **least distance of distinct vision** or the **near point**.
For a young adult with normal vision, the near point is about **25 cm**.
The farthest point up to which the eye can see objects clearly is called the **far point**, which is **infinity** for a normal eye.
A normal eye can see objects clearly that are between **25 cm and infinity**.
**Cataract** is a condition where the crystalline lens becomes milky and cloudy, causing partial or complete loss of vision, which can be restored through surgery.

one_mark_questions.question: What is accommodation? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The ability of the eye lens to adjust its focal length is called accommodation.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the function of the ciliary muscles? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The ciliary muscles modify the curvature of the eye lens, which in turn changes its focal length.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the near point of the eye? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The minimum distance at which objects can be seen most distinctly without strain is called the near point or the least distance of distinct vision.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the near point for a young adult with normal vision? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: For a young adult with normal vision, the near point is about 25 cm.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the far point of a normal eye? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The farthest point up to which the eye can see objects clearly is called the far point. For a normal eye, this is infinity.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the range of vision for a normal human eye? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: A normal eye can see objects clearly that are between 25 cm and infinity.

one_mark_questions.question: What is a cataract? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Cataract is a condition where the crystalline lens becomes milky and cloudy, causing partial or complete loss of vision.

one_mark_questions.question: How can vision be restored in a person with a cataract? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Vision can be restored through cataract surgery.

two_mark_questions.question: What happens to the eye lens and its focal length when viewing distant objects? (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: When viewing distant objects, the ciliary muscles are relaxed. This makes the eye lens thin, which increases its focal length, enabling a clear view.

two_mark_questions.question: What happens to the eye lens and its focal length when viewing nearby objects? (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: When viewing nearby objects, the ciliary muscles contract. This makes the eye lens thicker, which decreases its focal length, enabling a clear view.

two_mark_questions.question: Define the near point and the far point for a normal eye. (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer:
1. **Near Point:** The minimum distance at which objects can be seen distinctly without strain (about 25 cm). 
2. **Far Point:** The farthest point up to which the eye can see objects clearly (infinity).

three_mark_questions.question: Explain how the ciliary muscles help the eye focus on objects at different distances. (3 marks)
three_mark_questions.answer:
The ciliary muscles control the curvature of the eye lens. 
1. **For distant objects:** The muscles relax, making the lens thin. This increases the focal length. 
2. **For nearby objects:** The muscles contract, making the lens thicker. This decreases the focal length. 
This ability to adjust focal length is called accommodation.

three_mark_questions.question: Define (a) Power of Accommodation, (b) Near Point, and (c) Cataract. (3 marks)
three_mark_questions.answer:
(a) **Power of Accommodation:** The ability of the eye lens to adjust its focal length. 
(b) **Near Point:** The minimum distance (about 25 cm for a normal eye) at which objects can be seen most distinctly without strain. 
(c) **Cataract:** A condition where the crystalline lens becomes milky and cloudy, causing loss of vision.

five_mark_questions.question: What is meant by the power of accommodation? How does the eye lens change to see (a) distant objects and (b) nearby objects clearly? What are the near point and far point of a normal eye? (5 marks)
five_mark_questions.answer:
The ability of the eye lens to adjust its focal length to see both distant and near objects clearly is called the power of accommodation. 
(a) **Distant Objects:** The ciliary muscles relax, making the fibrous, jelly-like lens thin. This increases its focal length. 
(b) **Nearby Objects:** The ciliary muscles contract, causing the lens curvature to increase. The lens becomes thicker, and its focal length decreases. 
**Near Point:** The minimum distance for distinct vision, which is 25 cm for a normal eye. 
**Far Point:** The maximum distance the eye can see clearly, which is infinity for a normal eye.

topics.topic_name: DEFECTS OF VISION AND THEIR CORRECTION
key_concepts: The three common refractive defects of vision are **myopia (near-sightedness)**, **hypermetropia (far-sightedness)**, and **presbyopia**.
These defects can be corrected by the use of **suitable spherical lenses**.

one_mark_questions.question: What is myopia (near-sightedness)? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Myopia is a defect of vision in which a person can see nearby objects clearly but cannot see distant objects distinctly.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the cause of myopia? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Myopia is caused by (i) the excessive curvature of the eye lens, or (ii) the elongation of the eyeball.

one_mark_questions.question: Where is the image of a distant object formed in an eye with myopia? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: In a myopic eye, the image of a distant object is formed in front of the retina, and not on the retina itself.

one_mark_questions.question: How is myopia corrected? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Myopia is corrected by using a concave lens of a suitable power.

one_mark_questions.question: What is hypermetropia (far-sightedness)? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Hypermetropia is a defect of vision in which a person can see distant objects clearly but cannot see nearby objects distinctly.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the cause of hypermetropia? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Hypermetropia is caused by (i) the focal length of the eye lens being too long, or (ii) the eyeball becoming too short.

one_mark_questions.question: Where is the image of a nearby object formed in an eye with hypermetropia? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: In a hypermetropic eye, the image of a nearby object is formed behind the retina.

one_mark_questions.question: How is hypermetropia corrected? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Hypermetropia is corrected by using a convex lens of a suitable power.

one_mark_questions.question: What is presbyopia? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Presbyopia is the defect of vision due to which an old person cannot see nearby objects clearly due to the loss of power of accommodation.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the primary cause of presbyopia? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Presbyopia is an age-related condition caused by the gradual weakening of the ciliary muscles and the diminishing flexibility of the crystalline lens.

one_mark_questions.question: What type of lens is used to correct presbyopia? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: A convex lens of suitable power is used for correction. Sometimes, bifocal lenses are required if the person suffers from both myopia and hypermetropia.

two_mark_questions.question: State the two main causes of myopia. How is it corrected? (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer:
Causes: 
1. **Excessive curvature** of the eye lens, which makes its focal length short. 
2. **Elongation of the eyeball.** 
Correction: It is corrected using a **concave lens** of suitable power.

two_mark_questions.question: State the two main causes of hypermetropia. How is it corrected? (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer:
Causes: 
1. The **focal length of the eye lens is too long** (lens is not convex enough). 
2. The **eyeball has become too short.** 
Correction: It is corrected using a **convex lens** of suitable power.

two_mark_questions.question: What is presbyopia? What causes it? (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: Presbyopia is an age-related vision defect where a person finds it difficult to see nearby objects. It is caused by the gradual weakening of the ciliary muscles and the loss of flexibility of the eye lens, which reduces the eye's power of accommodation.

two_mark_questions.question: What are bifocal lenses? Who are they prescribed for? (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: Bifocal lenses consist of both concave and convex lenses. The upper portion is a concave lens (for distant vision), and the lower portion is a convex lens (for near vision). They are prescribed for people who suffer from both myopia and hypermetropia, a condition often associated with presbyopia.

three_mark_questions.question: Differentiate between myopia and hypermetropia in terms of (a) the defect, (b) the cause, and (c) the corrective lens. (3 marks)
three_mark_questions.answer:
(a) **Defect:** In myopia, distant objects are blurry. In hypermetropia, near objects are blurry. 
(b) **Cause:** Myopia is caused by an elongated eyeball or excessive lens curvature. Hypermetropia is caused by a shortened eyeball or a lens that is too flat (focal length too long). 
(c) **Correction:** Myopia is corrected with a concave lens. Hypermetropia is corrected with a convex lens.

three_mark_questions.question: Differentiate between hypermetropia and presbyopia. (3 marks)
three_mark_questions.answer:
Both defects cause difficulty in seeing nearby objects, but their causes differ. 
1. **Hypermetropia** is a refractive error caused by the eyeball being too short or the lens having too long a focal length. It can be present at any age. 
2. **Presbyopia** is an age-related condition that typically starts in middle age. It is caused by the loss of flexibility of the eye lens and the weakening of the ciliary muscles, which diminishes the eye's power of accommodation.

five_mark_questions.question: What is myopia? State its causes. Explain with a diagram how this defect is corrected. (5 marks)
five_mark_questions.answer:
**Myopia (Near-sightedness):** A vision defect where a person can see nearby objects clearly but not distant objects. 

**Causes:** 
1. **Excessive curvature of the eye lens:** This makes the lens too powerful, converging light rays at a short distance. 
2. **Elongation of the eyeball:** The distance between the lens and the retina is too large. 
In both cases, the image of a distant object is formed **in front of** the retina. 

**Correction:** 
Myopia is corrected using a **concave lens** of suitable power. This diverging lens spreads out the incoming light rays from a distant object *before* they enter the eye. This effectively moves the image backward, allowing the eye's lens to now focus it correctly **on the retina**.

five_mark_questions.question: What is hypermetropia? State its causes. Explain with a diagram how this defect is corrected. (5 marks)
five_mark_questions.answer:
**Hypermetropia (Far-sightedness):** A vision defect where a person can see distant objects clearly but finds it difficult to see nearby objects. 

**Causes:** 
1. **Focal length of the eye lens is too long:** The lens is not convex enough (insufficient converging power). 
2. **The eyeball has become too short:** The retina is too close to the eye lens. 
In both cases, the image of a nearby object is formed **behind** the retina. 

**Correction:** 
Hypermetropia is corrected using a **convex lens** of suitable power. This converging lens provides the extra focusing power needed. It bends the light rays inward *before* they enter the eye, allowing the eye's lens to focus the image forward **on the retina**.

key_concepts: **Myopia** is also known as near-sightedness.
A person with myopia can see **nearby objects clearly** but **cannot see distant objects distinctly**.
The image of a distant object is formed **in front of the retina** in a myopic eye.
Myopia arises due to **(i) excessive curvature of the eye lens** or **(ii) elongation of the eyeball**.
This defect is corrected by using a **concave lens** of suitable power.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the common name for myopia? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Myopia is also known as near-sightedness.

one_mark_questions.question: Describe the vision of a person with myopia. (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: A person with myopia can see nearby objects clearly but cannot see distant objects distinctly.

one_mark_questions.question: In an eye with myopia, where is the image of a distant object formed? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: In a myopic eye, the image of a distant object is formed in front of the retina.

one_mark_questions.question: State one cause of myopia. (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Myopia arises due to either (i) excessive curvature of the eye lens or (ii) elongation of the eyeball.

one_mark_questions.question: What type of lens is used to correct myopia? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Myopia is corrected by using a concave lens of suitable power.

two_mark_questions.question: What is myopia? How is it corrected? (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: Myopia (or near-sightedness) is a defect where a person can see nearby objects clearly but not distant ones. It is corrected by using a concave lens.

two_mark_questions.question: State the two possible causes of myopia. (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer:
Myopia arises due to: 
1. Excessive curvature of the eye lens. 
2. Elongation of the eyeball.

two_mark_questions.question: Why can't a person with myopia see distant objects clearly? (Refer to image formation) (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: A person with myopia cannot see distant objects clearly because the image of a distant object is formed in front of the retina, instead of directly on it.

three_mark_questions.question: What is myopia? State its two causes and the type of lens used to correct it. (3 marks)
three_mark_questions.answer: Myopia (near-sightedness) is a defect where a person sees nearby objects clearly but not distant ones. It is caused by (i) excessive curvature of the eye lens or (ii) elongation of the eyeball. It is corrected using a concave lens.

four_mark_questions.question: What is near-sightedness? Explain where the image is formed in this defect and why (state two causes). How is this defect corrected? (4 marks)
four_mark_questions.answer:
Near-sightedness, or myopia, is a vision defect where nearby objects are seen clearly, but distant objects are blurry. 
**Image Formation:** The image of a distant object is formed in front of the retina. 
**Causes:** This happens due to (i) excessive curvature of the eye lens or (ii) elongation of the eyeball. 
**Correction:** The defect is corrected using a concave lens of suitable power.

key_concepts: **Hypermetropia** is also known as far-sightedness.
A person with hypermetropia can see **distant objects clearly** but **cannot see nearby objects distinctly**.
The near point is farther away from the normal near point (25 cm).
The light rays from a close object are focussed at a point **behind the retina**.
Hypermetropia arises either because **(i) the focal length of the eye lens is too long** or **(ii) the eyeball has become too small**.
This defect is corrected by using a **convex lens (converging lenses)** of appropriate power.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the common name for hypermetropia? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Hypermetropia is also known as far-sightedness.

one_mark_questions.question: Describe the vision of a person with hypermetropia. (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: A person with hypermetropia can see distant objects clearly but cannot see nearby objects distinctly.

one_mark_questions.question: In an eye with hypermetropia, where is the image of a nearby object formed? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: In a hypermetropic eye, light rays from a close object are focussed at a point behind the retina.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the state of the near point for a hypermetropic eye? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The near point for a person with hypermetropia is farther away from the normal near point (25 cm).

one_mark_questions.question: State one of two reasons why hypermetropia arises. (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Hypermetropia arises either because (i) the focal length of the eye lens is too long or (ii) the eyeball has become too small.

one_mark_questions.question: What type of lens is used to correct hypermetropia? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: This defect is corrected by using a convex lens (a converging lens) of appropriate power.

two_mark_questions.question: What is hypermetropia? What type of lens is used to correct it? (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: Hypermetropia (or far-sightedness) is a defect where a person can see distant objects clearly but not nearby objects. It is corrected by using a convex (converging) lens.

two_mark_questions.question: State the two possible causes of hypermetropia. (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer:
Hypermetropia arises either because: 
1. The focal length of the eye lens is too long. 
2. The eyeball has become too small.

two_mark_questions.question: Why can't a person with hypermetropia see nearby objects distinctly? (Refer to image formation) (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: A person with hypermetropia cannot see nearby objects distinctly because the light rays from a close object are focussed at a point behind the retina, not on it.

three_mark_questions.question: What is hypermetropia? State its two causes and the type of lens used to correct it. (3 marks)
three_mark_questions.answer:
Hypermetropia (far-sightedness) is a defect where a person sees distant objects clearly but not nearby ones. 
It is caused by (i) the focal length of the eye lens being too long or (ii) the eyeball becoming too small. 
It is corrected using a convex (converging) lens.

four_mark_questions.question: What is far-sightedness? Explain why it occurs (state two causes) and where the image is formed. How is this defect corrected? (4 marks)
four_mark_questions.answer:
Far-sightedness, or hypermetropia, is a vision defect where distant objects are seen clearly, but nearby objects are blurry. 
**Image Formation:** The light rays from a close object are focussed at a point behind the retina. 
**Causes:** This happens because (i) the focal length of the eye lens is too long or (ii) the eyeball has become too small. 
**Correction:** The defect is corrected using a convex (converging) lens of appropriate power.

key_concepts: **Presbyopia** is the defect where the power of accommodation decreases with ageing, making it difficult to see nearby objects.
It arises due to the **gradual weakening of the ciliary muscles** and the **diminishing flexibility of the eye lens**.
People suffering from both myopia and hypermetropia often require **bi-focal lenses**.
Bi-focal lenses consist of a **concave lens in the upper portion** (for distant vision) and a **convex lens in the lower part** (for near vision).

one_mark_questions.question: What is presbyopia? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Presbyopia is the defect where the power of accommodation decreases with ageing, making it difficult to see nearby objects.

one_mark_questions.question: State one of the two main causes of presbyopia. (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Presbyopia arises due to (i) the gradual weakening of the ciliary muscles or (ii) the diminishing flexibility of the eye lens.

one_mark_questions.question: What type of lenses are required for people suffering from both myopia and hypermetropia? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: People suffering from both myopia and hypermetropia often require bi-focal lenses.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the function of the upper portion of a bi-focal lens? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The upper portion of a bi-focal lens consists of a concave lens and is used for distant vision.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the function of the lower portion of a bi-focal lens? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The lower part of a bi-focal lens consists of a convex lens and is used for near vision.

two_mark_questions.question: What is presbyopia and what are its two main causes? (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer:
Presbyopia is the defect where the power of accommodation decreases with ageing, making it difficult to see nearby objects. It arises due to: 
1. The gradual weakening of the ciliary muscles. 
2. The diminishing flexibility of the eye lens.

two_mark_questions.question: Describe the structure of a bi-focal lens and state its purpose. (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: A bi-focal lens consists of a concave lens in the upper portion (for distant vision) and a convex lens in the lower part (for near vision). Its purpose is to correct the vision of people suffering from both myopia and hypermetropia.

three_mark_questions.question: What is presbyopia? Why does it occur? What corrective measure is often used for people who have this defect along with myopia? (3 marks)
three_mark_questions.answer:
1. **Presbyopia:** It is the defect where the power of accommodation decreases with ageing, making it hard to see nearby objects. 
2. **Causes:** It arises from the gradual weakening of the ciliary muscles and the diminishing flexibility of the eye lens. 
3. **Correction:** People suffering from both this and myopia (myopia + hypermetropia/presbyopia) often require bi-focal lenses.

three_mark_questions.question: Explain the structure and function of bi-focal lenses. (3 marks)
three_mark_questions.answer:
Bi-focal lenses are used for people with both myopia and hypermetropia. 
1. **Structure:** They consist of two parts. The upper portion is a concave lens, and the lower part is a convex lens. 
2. **Function:** The upper concave lens corrects myopia, allowing for clear distant vision. The lower convex lens corrects hypermetropia/presbyopia, allowing for clear near vision.

topics.topic_name: REFRACTION OF LIGHT THROUGH A PRISM
key_concepts: A triangular glass prism has two triangular bases and three rectangular lateral surfaces that are inclined to each other.
The angle between the two lateral faces of a prism is called the **angle of the prism**.
When light enters from air to glass at the first surface, it **bends towards the normal**.
When light enters from glass to air at the second surface, it **bends away from the normal**.
The peculiar shape of the prism makes the emergent ray bend at an angle to the direction of the incident ray.
The angle between the incident ray and the emergent ray is called the **angle of deviation ($\angle	ext{D}$)**.

one_mark_questions.question: Describe the basic structure of a triangular glass prism. (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: A triangular glass prism has two triangular bases and three rectangular lateral surfaces.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the angle of the prism? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The angle between the two lateral faces of a prism is called the angle of the prism.

one_mark_questions.question: How does a ray of light bend when it enters a prism from air? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: When light enters from air to glass at the first surface, it bends towards the normal.

one_mark_questions.question: How does a ray of light bend when it emerges from a prism into the air? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: When light enters from glass to air at the second surface, it bends away from the normal.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the angle of deviation ($∠D$)? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The angle between the incident ray and the emergent ray is called the angle of deviation ($∠D$).

two_mark_questions.question: Define the 'angle of the prism' and the 'angle of deviation'. (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer:
1. **Angle of the Prism:** The angle between the two lateral faces of a prism. 
2. **Angle of Deviation ($∠D$):** The angle between the direction of the incident ray and the emergent ray.

two_mark_questions.question: Describe the path of light as it passes through a glass prism. (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: When light enters from air into the glass at the first surface, it bends towards the normal. When it emerges from the glass back into the air at the second surface, it bends away from the normal.

three_mark_questions.question: Explain why an emergent ray bends at an angle to the incident ray in a prism. Define this angle. (3 marks)
three_mark_questions.answer: When light enters the prism from air, it bends towards the normal. When it leaves the prism into the air, it bends away from the normal. Due to the peculiar shape of the prism (the two lateral faces are inclined), the emergent ray bends at an angle to the direction of the incident ray. This angle is known as the angle of deviation ($∠D$).

topics.topic_name: DISPERSION OF WHITE LIGHT BY A GLASS PRISM
key_concepts: The band of the coloured components of a light beam is called its **spectrum**.
The spectrum of white light contains the sequence of colours: **Violet, Indigo, Blue, Green, Yellow, Orange, and Red (VIBGYOR)**.
The **dispersion** of light is the **splitting of light into its component colours**.
White light is dispersed into seven-colour components by a prism because **different colours of light bend through different angles** as they pass through.
The **red light bends the least** while the **violet light bends the most**.
**Isaac Newton** was the first to obtain the spectrum of sunlight using a glass prism.
Newton demonstrated that sunlight is made up of seven colours by using a second, identical, **inverted prism** to recombine the spectrum back into **white light**.
A **rainbow** is a natural spectrum caused by **dispersion of sunlight by tiny water droplets** in the atmosphere.
A rainbow is always formed in a direction **opposite to that of the Sun**.
Water droplets act like small prisms: they **refract, disperse, reflect internally, and then refract again** when light comes out.

one_mark_questions.question: What is a spectrum? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The band of the coloured components of a light beam is called its spectrum.

one_mark_questions.question: What is dispersion of light? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The splitting of light into its component colours is called dispersion.

one_mark_questions.question: Which colour of light bends the least when passed through a prism? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The red light bends the least.

one_mark_questions.question: Which colour of light bends the most when passed through a prism? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The violet light bends the most.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the acronym for the sequence of colours in the white light spectrum? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: VIBGYOR (Violet, Indigo, Blue, Green, Yellow, Orange, and Red).

one_mark_questions.question: Who was the first person to use a glass prism to obtain the spectrum of sunlight? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Isaac Newton was the first to obtain the spectrum of sunlight using a glass prism.

one_mark_questions.question: What natural phenomenon is caused by the dispersion of sunlight by tiny water droplets? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: A rainbow is a natural spectrum caused by dispersion of sunlight by tiny water droplets.

one_mark_questions.question: In which direction is a rainbow always formed? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: A rainbow is always formed in a direction opposite to that of the Sun.

two_mark_questions.question: Why does a prism disperse white light into its seven-colour components? (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: White light is dispersed because different colours of light bend through different angles as they pass through the prism. Red light bends the least, while violet light bends the most.

two_mark_questions.question: How did Isaac Newton demonstrate that sunlight is made up of seven colours? (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: He first obtained a spectrum using a glass prism. He then placed a second, identical, inverted prism in the path of the spectrum, which recombined the seven colours back into white light.

two_mark_questions.question: What two phenomena must occur inside a water droplet to produce a rainbow? (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: Water droplets act like small prisms. They first refract and disperse the sunlight, then reflect it internally, and finally refract it again when it comes out of the droplet.

three_mark_questions.question: What is a rainbow? How is it formed? (3 marks)
three_mark_questions.answer: A rainbow is a natural spectrum of sunlight. It is caused by the dispersion of sunlight by tiny water droplets in the atmosphere, which act like small prisms. The light is refracted, dispersed, internally reflected, and then refracted again as it emerges from the droplet.

three_mark_questions.question: Explain the terms 'spectrum' and 'dispersion'. Which colour in the spectrum bends the most, and which bends the least? (3 marks)
three_mark_questions.answer:
1. **Spectrum:** The band of the coloured components of a light beam (e.g., VIBGYOR for white light). 
2. **Dispersion:** The splitting of light into its component colours. 
3. **Bending:** Violet light bends the most, and red light bends the least.

key_concepts: **Atmospheric refraction** is the refraction of light by the earth's atmosphere.
Hot air is **lighter (less dense)** than cooler air and has a **refractive index slightly less** than cooler air.
The random wavering or flickering of objects seen through turbulent hot air is an effect of atmospheric refraction.
The **twinkling of stars** is due to atmospheric refraction of starlight on a larger scale.
The atmosphere bends starlight **towards the normal**, making the **apparent position of the star slightly higher** than its actual position near the horizon.
The apparent position of a star fluctuates because the **physical conditions of the earth's atmosphere are not stationary**.
Planets do not twinkle because they are much **closer to the earth** and are seen as **extended sources** (collections of point-sized sources).
Atmospheric refraction causes the Sun to be visible about **2 minutes before the actual sunrise** and about **2 minutes after the actual sunset**.

one_mark_questions.question: What is atmospheric refraction? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Atmospheric refraction is the refraction of light by the earth's atmosphere.

one_mark_questions.question: How does the refractive index of hot air compare to that of cooler air? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Hot air is less dense and has a refractive index slightly less than cooler air.

one_mark_questions.question: What phenomenon causes the twinkling of stars? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The twinkling of stars is due to the atmospheric refraction of starlight.

one_mark_questions.question: What phenomenon causes the apparent flickering of objects seen through hot air? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The random wavering or flickering of objects seen through turbulent hot air is an effect of atmospheric refraction.

one_mark_questions.question: Why does the apparent position of a star appear slightly higher than its actual position? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: As starlight enters the atmosphere, it bends towards the normal, making the apparent position of the star slightly higher.

one_mark_questions.question: Why do planets not twinkle? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Planets are much closer to the earth and are seen as extended sources, so the twinkling effects from different points average out.

one_mark_questions.question: By how much time does atmospheric refraction advance the sunrise? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Atmospheric refraction causes the Sun to be visible about 2 minutes before the actual sunrise.

one_mark_questions.question: By how much time does atmospheric refraction delay the sunset? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Atmospheric refraction causes the Sun to be visible about 2 minutes after the actual sunset.

two_mark_questions.question: Explain why the apparent position of a star fluctuates. (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: The apparent position of a star fluctuates because the physical conditions of the earth's atmosphere (e.g., temperature, density) are not stationary, causing the path of the starlight to vary.

two_mark_questions.question: Explain the phenomenon of advanced sunrise and delayed sunset. (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: Due to atmospheric refraction, the atmosphere bends sunlight towards us. This allows us to see the Sun about 2 minutes before it actually rises above the horizon (advanced sunrise) and for about 2 minutes after it has set (delayed sunset).

two_mark_questions.question: Why do stars twinkle but planets do not? (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: Stars twinkle because they are point-sized sources, and their light path is easily disturbed by the changing atmosphere. Planets are closer and are extended sources (collections of points), so the variations in light from all points average out, nullifying the twinkling effect.

two_mark_questions.question: How does the atmosphere affect the apparent position of a star near the horizon? (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: The atmosphere's density increases closer to the earth. As starlight enters the atmosphere, it continuously bends towards the normal. This makes the apparent position of the star appear slightly higher than its actual position.

three_mark_questions.question: What is atmospheric refraction? Explain why stars twinkle. (3 marks)
three_mark_questions.answer: Atmospheric refraction is the refraction (bending) of light by the earth's atmosphere. Stars twinkle because the starlight has to travel through the atmosphere, which has continuously changing physical conditions (density, temperature). This causes the light path to fluctuate, making the apparent position of the star change and the amount of light entering the eye flicker.

three_mark_questions.question: Explain in detail why planets do not twinkle. (3 marks)
three_mark_questions.answer: Planets are much closer to the Earth than stars and are seen as extended sources, not point-sized sources. We can think of a planet as a collection of many point-sized sources. The light from all these individual points passes through the atmosphere, but the twinkling (dimming and brightening) effects from each point average out. The total variation in the amount of light entering the eye is nullified, so planets do not appear to twinkle.

three_mark_questions.question: What causes advanced sunrise and delayed sunset? How much is the day lengthened by this phenomenon? (3 marks)
three_mark_questions.answer: Advanced sunrise and delayed sunset are caused by atmospheric refraction. When the Sun is slightly below the horizon, its light travels through the atmosphere and is bent (refracted) downwards towards the observer. This makes the Sun appear to be above the horizon. This causes the Sun to be visible about 2 minutes before actual sunrise and 2 minutes after actual sunset, lengthening the day by a total of about 4 minutes.

four_mark_questions.question:
(a) What is atmospheric refraction? 
(b) Explain why stars twinkle. 
(c) Explain why planets do not twinkle. (4 marks)
four_mark_questions.answer:
(a) **Atmospheric refraction** is the refraction of light by the earth's atmosphere. 
(b) **Twinkling of stars:** Stars are distant, point-sized sources of light. As their light passes through the earth's non-stationary atmosphere, the light path fluctuates, causing the apparent position and brightness to change, which we see as twinkling. 
(c) **Planets do not twinkle:** Planets are closer and are extended sources. They are a collection of point-sized sources, and the twinkling effects from all these points average out, nullifying the effect.

key_concepts: The interplay of light with objects gives rise to phenomena like the blue colour of the sky, the colour of deep sea water, and the reddening of the sun at sunrise/sunset.

one_mark_questions.question: What general process gives rise to phenomena like the blue colour of the sky? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The interplay of light with objects (specifically, the scattering of light by particles) gives rise to these phenomena.

one_mark_questions.question: List two natural phenomena caused by the interplay of light with objects in the atmosphere. (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Two phenomena are the blue colour of the sky and the reddening of the sun at sunrise and sunset. (Also acceptable: colour of deep sea water).

two_mark_questions.question: What is the general cause of the blue colour of the sky and the reddening of the sun at sunrise? (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: These phenomena are caused by the interplay of light with objects, specifically the scattering of light by particles in the atmosphere.

key_concepts: The earth's atmosphere is a **heterogeneous mixture** of minute particles (smoke, water droplets, dust, air molecules).
When a beam of light strikes these fine particles, the **path of the beam becomes visible**.
The light reaches us after being **reflected diffusely** by these particles.
The phenomenon of **scattering of light by colloidal particles** is called the **Tyndall effect**.
The **colour of the scattered light depends on the size** of the scattering particles.
**Very fine particles scatter mainly blue light** (shorter wavelengths).
**Larger particles scatter light of longer wavelengths**, and if the size is large enough, the scattered light appears white.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the Tyndall effect? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The phenomenon of scattering of light by colloidal particles is called the Tyndall effect.

one_mark_questions.question: What kind of mixture is the earth's atmosphere? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The earth's atmosphere is a heterogeneous mixture of minute particles (smoke, water droplets, dust, air molecules).

one_mark_questions.question: What happens when a beam of light strikes fine particles in the atmosphere? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: When a beam of light strikes these fine particles, the path of the beam becomes visible.

one_mark_questions.question: What does the colour of the scattered light depend on? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The colour of the scattered light depends on the size of the scattering particles.

one_mark_questions.question: What colour of light do very fine particles scatter most effectively? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Very fine particles scatter mainly blue light (shorter wavelengths).

one_mark_questions.question: What kind of light do larger-sized particles scatter? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Larger particles scatter light of longer wavelengths. If the size is very large, the scattered light may appear white.

two_mark_questions.question: What is the Tyndall effect? Why does the path of light become visible? (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: The Tyndall effect is the scattering of light by colloidal particles. The path becomes visible because the light reaches us after being reflected diffusely (scattered) by these particles.

two_mark_questions.question: Explain how particle size affects the colour of scattered light. (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: The colour depends on the particle size. Very fine particles scatter mainly blue light (shorter wavelengths). Larger particles scatter light of longer wavelengths, and if they are large enough, the scattered light appears white.

two_mark_questions.question: Give an example of the Tyndall effect in the atmosphere. (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: The Tyndall effect is seen when a beam of sunlight enters a smoky or dusty room. The path of the light becomes visible because the fine dust and smoke particles in the air scatter the light.

three_mark_questions.question: What is the Tyndall effect? Explain what determines the colour of the scattered light. (3 marks)
three_mark_questions.answer:
1. **Tyndall Effect:** The phenomenon of scattering of light by colloidal (fine) particles. 
2. **Colour:** The colour of the scattered light depends on the size of the scattering particles. 
3. **Explanation:** Very fine particles scatter mainly blue light (shorter wavelengths), while larger particles scatter light of longer wavelengths. If particles are large enough, the scattered light may appear white.

subtopics.subtopic_name: Why is the colour of the clear Sky Blue?
key_concepts: Molecules of air and fine particles are **smaller than the wavelength of visible light**.
They are more effective in scattering light of **shorter wavelengths (blue end)** than light of longer wavelengths (red end).
The **red light has a wavelength about 1.8 times greater than blue light**.
When sunlight passes through the atmosphere, the fine particles scatter the blue colour more strongly, and this scattered blue light enters our eyes.
If the earth had no atmosphere, there would be no scattering, and the sky would look **dark**.
The sky appears dark to passengers flying at **very high altitudes** because scattering is not prominent there.
'Danger' signal lights are **red** because red is **least scattered by fog or smoke** and can be seen in the same colour at a distance.

one_mark_questions.question: Why does the clear sky appear blue? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Fine particles in the atmosphere scatter blue light (shorter wavelengths) more strongly than red light, and this scattered blue light enters our eyes.

one_mark_questions.question: What colour of light is scattered most effectively by fine particles in the air? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Light of shorter wavelengths, at the blue end of the spectrum, is scattered most effectively.

one_mark_questions.question: What colour of light is scattered least by fog or smoke? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Red light is scattered the least by fog or smoke.

one_mark_questions.question: Why are 'danger' signal lights red? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: Danger signals are red because red light is scattered the least by fog or smoke and can be seen clearly from a distance.

one_mark_questions.question: What would the colour of the sky be if the Earth had no atmosphere? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: If the Earth had no atmosphere, there would be no scattering, and the sky would look dark.

one_mark_questions.question: How does the wavelength of red light compare to blue light? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The red light has a wavelength about 1.8 times greater than blue light.

one_mark_questions.question: Why does the sky appear dark at very high altitudes? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: At very high altitudes, scattering is not prominent, so the sky appears dark.

two_mark_questions.question: Explain the role of particle size in the scattering of light. (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: Molecules of air and other fine particles are smaller than the wavelength of visible light. They are more effective in scattering light of shorter wavelengths (blue end) than light of longer wavelengths (red end).

two_mark_questions.question: Explain why the sky is blue, but danger signals are red. (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer:
1. **Sky:** Fine air particles scatter short-wavelength blue light most strongly, which enters our eyes. 
2. **Danger Signals:** Red light has a long wavelength and is scattered the least, allowing it to travel farther through fog or smoke.

two_mark_questions.question: What would happen to the colour of the sky if the Earth had no atmosphere, and why? (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: The sky would look dark. This is because the blue colour of the sky is caused by the scattering of sunlight by particles in the atmosphere. Without an atmosphere, there would be no scattering.

three_mark_questions.question: Explain in detail why the clear sky appears blue. (3 marks)
three_mark_questions.answer: The atmosphere contains air molecules and fine particles smaller than the wavelength of visible light. These particles are more effective at scattering light of shorter wavelengths (the blue end of the spectrum) than longer wavelengths (the red end). When sunlight passes through the atmosphere, this blue light is scattered in all directions. When we look at the sky, this scattered blue light enters our eyes, making the sky appear blue.

key_concepts: If the electric charge flows through a conductor (e.g., a metallic wire), there is an **electric current** in the conductor.
An electric current is the **rate of flow of electric charges**.
In circuits using metallic wires, **electrons** constitute the flow of charges.
A **continuous and closed path** of an electric current is called an **electric circuit**.
Conventionally, the direction of electric current is taken as **opposite to the direction of the flow of electrons** (negative charges).
If a net charge $	ext{Q}$, flows across a conductor in time $	ext{t}$, the current $	ext{I}$ is given by: $$I=\frac{Q}{t}$$
The **SI unit of electric charge is coulomb ($	ext{C}$)**.
One coulomb is equivalent to the charge contained in nearly $6\times10^{18}$ electrons.
The **electric current is expressed by a unit called ampere ($	ext{A}$)**.
One ampere is constituted by the flow of **one coulomb of charge per second** ($1	ext{ A}=1	ext{ C}/1	ext{ s}$ ).
An instrument called **ammeter** measures electric current and is always connected in **series** in a circuit.
Electric current flows in the circuit from the **positive terminal** of the cell to the **negative terminal**.

one_mark_questions.question: What is an electric current? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: An electric current is the rate of flow of electric charges.

one_mark_questions.question: What is an electric circuit? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: A continuous and closed path of an electric current is called an electric circuit.

one_mark_questions.question: What particles constitute the flow of charges in metallic wires? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: In circuits using metallic wires, electrons constitute the flow of charges.

one_mark_questions.question: What is the conventional direction of electric current? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The direction of electric current is conventionally taken as opposite to the direction of the flow of electrons.

one_mark_questions.question: State the formula relating electric current (I), charge (Q), and time (t). (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: I = Q/t

one_mark_questions.question: What is the SI unit of electric charge? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The SI unit of electric charge is the coulomb (C).

one_mark_questions.question: What is the SI unit of electric current? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: The electric current is expressed by a unit called the ampere (A).

one_mark_questions.question: Define one ampere. (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: One ampere is constituted by the flow of one coulomb of charge per second (1 A = 1 C/1 s).

one_mark_questions.question: What instrument measures electric current? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: An instrument called an ammeter measures electric current.

one_mark_questions.question: How is an ammeter connected in a circuit? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: An ammeter is always connected in series in a circuit.

one_mark_questions.question: How many electrons are in one coulomb of charge? (1 mark)
one_mark_questions.answer: One coulomb is equivalent to the charge contained in nearly 6 x 10^18 electrons.

two_mark_questions.question: Define electric current and state its SI unit. (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: Electric current is the rate of flow of electric charges. The SI unit of electric current is the ampere (A).

two_mark_questions.question: What is an ammeter? How is it connected in a circuit? (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer: An ammeter is an instrument used to measure electric current. It is always connected in series in the circuit.

two_mark_questions.question: Define 1 ampere and 1 coulomb. (2 marks)
two_mark_questions.answer:
1 Ampere: The flow of one coulomb of charge per second. 
1 Coulomb: The charge contained in nearly 6 x 10^18 electrons.
